Hi C.,
This is Jeff from 
Calendly
 with some tips and product updates to make meetings easier and more productive.
Tip of the Day: You Deserve to 
Get Paid
You should be 
charging people money to “pick your brain” in a video call
. To give them feedback on their startup. To teach them about your profession. To consult at night after your long workday. To demo their product. To coach them each week. To teach them yoga or exercise or art or music.
Yes, we should all volunteer to help people who don’t have the means to pay us. However, many of the people who reach out to you on LinkedIn do.
The “side hustles” to create another revenue stream in 2022 are now the necessary protection you need in an uncertain economy in 2024.
Join me and thousands of others, and 
connect your Calendly to PayPal or Stripe and start charging for meetings
 (available on the 
Standard subscription plan
 and higher).
You don’t need to request people pay for every meeting if you have 
multiple event types
 that you offer, but reserve one event type with 
PayPal
 or 
Stripe
 integrated – just in case. 
Charge for Meetings
Back That Event Type Up
As you know, Calendly Event Types are how you offer your attendees blocks of time to meet with you (e.g., 30-minute video call, 15-minute in-person visit, 45-minute paid consultation).
Sometimes you need a little backup when coordinating meetings. That’s why we recently expanded 
event type permissions
, allowing you to add editors and viewers to your own events 
and
 admin-managed events!
Collaborators can make event updates that help you deliver the best customer and candidate experience, prepare event types for you to speed up scheduling, and share event links on your behalf for a seamless handoff.
Try Permissions
Improved Collective and Round Robin Event Types
When I ask people in companies what their favorite Calendly feature is, they generally say our 
collaborative scheduling features
 to schedule better together as a team.
These team-scheduling pros wanted more, though. Dozens of them emailed asking for the ability to share meetings among groups of coworkers, or what we call 
Collective 
plus
 Round Robin
.
Available on the 
Teams and Enterprise subscription plans
, you can now mix and match Collective and Round Robin capabilities to easily get a combination of teammates scheduled. For example, you can improve: 
Product demos to prospects:
 Set up an event type with an account executive plus one of five rotating sales engineers
Panel interviews:
 Pair a hiring manager with one of three rotating team leaders plus one of four rotating peers interviewers
New customer onboarding calls:
 Include a sales manager who closed the deal plus their assigned customer success manager and one of four rotating technical implementation specialists
Try Collective and Round Robin
Join Your Calendly Community
Have you ever wanted to 
meet other Calendly users
? What about ask them questions? Or answer theirs? We’ve got you covered with the new 
Calendly Community
, your go-to hub for answers, inspiration, and all things scheduling.
Whether you’re just getting started making your scheduling more efficient or a seasoned pro, this community has something for you.
Ready to check it out? Head on over to 
Calendly Community
 and explore. 
Explore Calendly Community
Webinars We Recommend
Getting Started With Calendly
Using Calendly as a Team
Sales and Marketing: 
How to Fill Pipeline During Economic Uncertainty
 
Customer Success and Support: 
Build a Better Journey for Retention: Pro Tips for CS Teams
 
Recruiting: 
Hire Faster with Calendly: Pro Tips for Recruiters
 
Education: 
How Dartmouth Supports Student Wellbeing with Calendly
 
Financial Services: 
How Financial Services Companies Drive Revenue with Calendly
 
Thanks for reading, 
Jeff Hardison
Head of Product Marketing @ Calendly
Need help?
  
Help Center
 ‌ | ‌ 
Pricing & FAQs
 ‌ | ‌ 
Contact Us
 
More than a scheduling link.
 
 
 
 
 
115 E. Main Street, Suite A1B, Buford, GA 30518
www.calendly.com

China 
Kangxin Partners PC 
Winning strategies for resolving domain name disputes in China
 
The rapidly evolving and competitive nature of the Internet carries a high risk of infringement. For rights holders of domain names in China, it is vital to understand the different dispute resolution methods in order to effectively protect their assets.
Authors:
Fiona Zhang
 
Insight 
HongFangLaw IP Consulting Firm
 
Bob Zhang
 
Protecting brands online in the wake of covid-19 and the surge in tech developments
 
Featured in 
Inside China’s IP Market: a Guide 2024
 
Consumers have grown accustomed to purchasing goods and services through various online channels, and these new e-commerce models have made IP rights infringement even more widespread. This is presenting fresh challenges in brand protection, evidence collection, enforcement models and legal applications. 
Read more »
 
Cassels Brock & Blackwell LLP
 
Steven Kennedy
 
Jennifer McKenzie
 
Sebastian Beck-Watt
 
Canada: New Legislation Presents Fresh Challenges for Applicants
 
Featured in 
The Trademark Prosecution Review 2024
 
Since Canada’s legislative overhaul in 2019, practitioners, brand owners, the courts and the Canadian Intellectual Property Office have all had to adapt to various new challenges. Much like the country’s famous maple syrup, Canada’s trademark regime can be slow and sticky for the unwary. However, with the right tools, robust trademark protection is readily available. 
Read more »

subject: Become a Sponsor for SIETAR Congress'24
body:
You don't often get email from no-reply@sietareu.org. 
Learn why this is important
View this email in your browser
 
Dear SIETAR Sympathizer, 
With this letter, we would like to remind you that you still have an opportunity to support the SIETAR Europa Congress in Lille!
SIETAR Europa is a non-profit, non-governmental international organization in Europe affiliated with the global network of SIETAR Organisations around the world. Its purpose is to encourage the development and application of knowledge, values, and skills that enable effective intercultural and interethnic relations at the individual, group, organization, and community levels. 
Every two years
 we celebrate a congress that serves as a forum to exchange recent research and best practices in our field. The 2024 congress will be taking place at the IÉSEG School of Management in Lille, France from June 5th to 8th.  
This year’s theme is 
Systems: The Ecosystem of Interculturalism.
 From neuroscience to anti-racist justice, from migration studies to critical history: new voices, paradigms, and perspectives begin to have a significant influence on how we make sense of interculturalism. Our 2024 Congress wants to explore these systemic dependencies and place interculturalism into a paradigm that looks ahead by acknowledging its past and that shapes its future with intention – together. 
Therefore, we invite you and your organization to 
become sponsors for this congress
. It is through the generous support of institutions like yours that we can bring forth this space for exchange and learning.  
We are inviting you to showcase your organization and expand the reach of your services. We are expecting approximately 
400+ attendees at next year’s congress. 
There are various ways in which you can contribute as a sponsor. All the information is available on our website: 
https://lille24.sietareu.org/p/sponsorship
.You can also look at the 
brochure
 for more details.
​
If you wish to sponsor the congress, please complete the registration form below
Become a sponsor
 
We are looking forward to your interest and availability to become a sponsor of one of the most sustainable events ever. 
 
Best regards, 
Almendra Staffa-Healey and Rima Sharma 
Sponsorship Committee Co-Chairs

Forward

subject: Training Industry Weekly Recap 📅 Jan 21, 2024
body:
Training Industry Magazine’s winter issue, new TI course and more.
View this email in your browser
THE BUSINESS OF LEARNING™
They say truth is stranger than fiction, but luckily, that has not been the case with artificial intelligence (AI). AI-powered tools have become indispensable for professionals worldwide, offering a wide range of applications that help us be more efficient and, more importantly, more effective.
This week, we have several resources that explore AI's expanding role in learning and development (L&D), highlighting its practicality and versatility in enhancing learning experiences. 
From our latest issue of 
Training Industry Magazine
 to our upcoming 
Leader Talk
, we have a wealth of expert insights to help you leverage AI-powered tools effectively in your L&D strategies — regardless of where your organization is on its AI journey. 
As always, we love hearing from you. Email us at 
editor@trainingindustry.com
 
with any comments or suggestions.  
Jenny Ayers 
Associate Editor 
Just Released: Training Industry Magazine’s Winter Issue
The Winter 2024 issue of 
Training Industry Magazine
 is out now! This edition features articles related to upskilling in the AI era, offering helpful insights from L&D professionals. Explore thought-provoking articles on driving skills transfer, crafting effective L&D strategies and more. Check it out now for expert strategies on how to utilize AI to transform your upskilling initiatives.
Read Now
 
[Leader Talk] AI-Powered Learning Solutions
Join us Jan. 31 for our complimentary 
Leader Talk
 where we’ll delve into how AI is reshaping roles and revolutionizing course development, personalized learning, coaching feedback and more. Our panel of L&D experts will provide insights into leveraging AI for practical L&D applications and balancing its benefits while avoiding over-dependence. Don't miss this opportunity to learn about making AI your ally in navigating the dynamic world of L&D.
Reserve Your Spot
 
New Course! Learning Analytics Workshop  
Registration is now open for Training Industry Courses’ 
Learning Analytics Workshop
! This half-day workshop provides a foundation to begin incorporating more effective analytics practices into your organization. You will learn about effective tools and techniques for data collection, preparation, analysis and presentation, giving you the confidence you need when sharing recommendations with your stakeholders. Learn more or register for the first session happening May 20 from 1-5 p.m. ET.
Learn More
 
[E-Book] The AI Advantage in L&D: A Strategic Guide
here is much uncertainty across the L&D community surrounding the potential applications and ethical considerations of artificial intelligence (AI). This Training Industry e-book examines the increasing impact and true potential of AI and large language models (LLMs) like ChatGPT in corporate training.

subject: World’s most valuable brand; EUIPO leadership complaint; US presidential race; and much more
body:
WTR SUNDAY DIGEST
21 January 2024
 
 
World’s most valuable brand; EUIPO leadership complaint; US presidential race; and much more
 
Everything we covered on WTR over the past seven days, and all you need to know from the world of trademarks to set yourself up for the start of another busy week.
 
Long Reads
 
A former candidate in the 
EUIPO leadership race
 voices concerns over the transparency of the selection process, following a complaint filed at the European Anti-fraud Office.
 
Local lawyers outline what have we learned from 
India's biggest
 cases of 2023.
 
Monday 15 January
 
Filing data analysis reveals what 
Peloton could have in store
 for its rebrand.
 
Rouse’s trademark team in Indonesia examines 
trends in oppositions
 filed in 2023.
 
We outline recent difficulties in 
proving genuine use
 of an EU trademark.
 
Plus:
Individuals who commit crimes against IP may be investigated as a criminal organisation
 (Peru)
Bulls bounce back: mixed success in PIZZA TEXAS BULLS appeal
 (United Kingdom)
 
Tuesday 16 January
 
We 
head to Bolivia
 in the next instalment of our series on brand protection at borders worldwide.
 
Uniqlo sues Shein, registration opens for the 2024 INTA Annual Meeting, the Thomas Cook brand is sold, 
and more
.
 
Plus:
How famous must one be? The difference between Lionel Messi, Miley Cyrus and Lewis Hamilton
 (European Union)
Domain name investor obtains finding of RDNH
 (International)
 
Wednesday 17 January
 
Apple smashes records to 
exceed half a trillion dollars
 in brand value, reclaiming its title as the world’s most valuable brand.
 
Brazilian trademark filings rise, Taiwan issues a fraud warning, the Spanish IP Office ditches fax, and more, in this week’s 
IP office updates
.
 
Plus:
General Court confirms lack of likelihood of confusion between SNACK marks
 (European Union)
Italian Supreme Court and EU General Court rule on protection of Vespa shape
 (Italy)
 
Thursday 18 January
 
The European Union 
loses €16 billion a year
 to fake clothing, cosmetics and toys, a new EUIPO report finds.
 
Trademarkia’s founder issues a 
“wake-up call” about AI
 and the future of the trademark profession.
 
Plus:
Pierre Balmain v EUIPO: the distinctiveness of a figurative mark consisting of a lion’s head
 (European Union)
Hilton unsuccessful in opposition against LX HOTEL/LX RESORT
 (Japan)
Vans parody loses out on heightened First Amendment protection in Second Circuit ruling
 (Market Insight: United States)
 
Friday 19 January
 
The commissioner of the 
Korean Intellectual Property Office resigns
 to run in the country’s general election.
 
US presidential candidate 
Nikki Haley faces trademark issues
 in the United States and China.
 
WeChat’s reputation triumphs
 against tough economic conditions as Chinese brands come to dominate the world’s strongest brand rankings.
 
Tencent’s CEO is named the 
world’s best brand guardian
, Louis Vuitton loses a trademark dispute, Napster makes metaverse plans, and more.
 
Plus:
Cross-border unfair competition dispute questions Belarus trademark registration
 (International)
Court of Appeal clarifies when acquiescence clock starts ticking
 (United Kingdom)
 
Saturday 20 January
 
2024 is shaping up to be a 
pivotal year for the EUIPO
, and users must remain front of mind, argues this week’s Saturday opinion.
 
Special Report: Safeguarding Style
 
WTR 
latest Special Report
 delves into the multifaceted landscape of brand creation and protection in the fashion and luxury industry, exploring the filing strategies, anti-counterfeiting technologies and international collaborations that are essential to success.

Cold email, hot tip: The milkshake tactic
Milkshakes are cold and sweet. 
Cold emails?
 Just cold. But with personalization, you can make them sweet.
Personalization is a great way to make your emails more successful. It helps you build a connection with the recipient.
And the milkshake tactic is a simple and effective way to personalize your email outreach at scale.
There are two ways to make that happen:
Paying your recipient a compliment,
Leveraging shared experience, background, etc.
Read our article about cold email personalization to learn more.

THE BUSINESS OF LEARNING™
The training function not only extends to employees but also to training professionals and anyone who leads learning in their organization. As learning leaders, continuous development is imperative to managing change and supporting a sustainable company — that’s fit for the future.
A 
case study

Certified Professional in Training Management (CPTM™)

The annual 
Training Industry Conference & Expo (TICE)
, June 4-6 in Raleigh, N.C., for three days of dynamic learning and networking with a community of training professionals. If you want to attend, but need approval from your boss, use our “
convince your boss
” template to outline why TICE is a wise investment. 
Our Training Industry Research e-book, 
“What Learners Want: New Strategies for Training Delivery,”
  for insights on how to avoid the pitfalls of lackluster training.  
We also have a great lineup of articles with tips to help you through your workday. As always, we love hearing from you. Email us at 
editor@trainingindustry.com
 with your thoughts and ideas. 
Danielle Johnson 
Associate Editor 
[Case Study] How Cruise Achieved Strategic Alignment with CPTM
With over 20 years of experience, Cheryl Haga, CPTM, led a high-tech startup company’s training team. In order to creating great alignment between L&D efforts and company goals, Haga's team earned their 
Certified Professional in Training Management (CPTM™)
 credential together. In this case study, we explore Haga’s journey with CPTM™ and share her insights on how to drive results as a learning leader.

subject: Copyright litigation trends; border protection tips; brand-backed financing plans; and much more
body:
WTR SUNDAY DIGEST
14 January 2024
 
 
Copyright litigation trends; border protection tips; brand-backed financing plans; and much more
 
Everything we covered on WTR over the past seven days, and all you need to know from the world of trademarks to set yourself up for the start of another busy week.
 
Long Read
 
An arrangement taking effect this month for the 
cross-border enforcement of judgments
 offers brand owners a new weapon in the face of infringement in Hong Kong and Mainland China.
 
Monday 8 January
 
The Korean IP Office confirms that it plans to “
lay the groundwork
” for brand-backed financing, as it seeks to expands IP valuation offerings.
 
The French IP office’s director of economic action calls for the harmonisation of global legislation 
to bolster the fight
 against fakes.
 
To kick off a series looking at recent Legal Updates you may have missed, we explored cases where rights holders have 
attempted to register or defend
 non-traditional trademarks.
 
Plus:
General Court confirms validity of Lego’s 3D mark for toy figure
 (European Union)
JPO finds that ADEAM ICHI is not similar to ICHI
 (Japan)
 
Tuesday 9 January
 
We head to Uruguay to explore 
how to safeguard brands
 at the country's borders and entry points.
 
Tuesday’s news digest includes coverage of BabyMonster prevailing in a dispute with Monster Energy, the Trademark Terminal website being 
put up for sale
, and much more.
 
A legal expert from Indonesia looks back at 2023, changing client needs, the 
rise of 3D trademarks
, and what the next 12 months have in store.
 
Plus:
Circular 23: filing procedures further clarified
 (Vietnam)
bet365 rolls the dice in General Court appeal
 (European Union)
 
Wednesday 10 January
 
The USPTO 
announces executive appointments
 and IPOS unveils new trademark features.
 
We continued our series highlighting recent Legal Updates by looking at success stories in 
the food and beverage sector
.
 
Filing data reveals 
rising activity
 across Latin America.
 
Plus:  
UDRP: bad faith difficult to prove for short acronyms
 (International)
The BILLBOARD battle: lessons learned from recent decision
 (Thailand)
 
Thursday 11 January
 
We head to Egypt 
for brand protection advice
 at the border.
 
Plus:
New Trademarks Act finally promulgated
 (Zambia)
Nullity claims against administrative acts involving industrial property rights: is conciliation a prerequisite for admissibility?
 (Colombia)
Cancellation actions could surge as TÜRKPATENT and Court of Appeal remain at odds over acquired rights principle
 (Market Insight: Türkiye)
 
Friday 12 January
 
NatWest launches 
IP-based lending
; TripAdvisor heads to the metaverse, Superdry promotes sustainable fashion, and more.
 
The Central District of California is the 
top US district court
 for copyright cases, with litigation data revealing key trends in the forum.
 
We explore cases where trademark owners in the 
luxury and fashion sector
 have successfully protected their rights.
 
Plus:
Pierre Hermé unsuccessful in opposition against HOUSE OF HERME
 (Japan)
Trademark filing history may lead to finding of bad faith
 (Türkiye)
 
Saturday 13 January
 
Clear guidance on the value of protected food and drink name status is vital to ensure businesses have the right amount of protection and are 
prepared to use it
, argues this week’s opinion.
 
Special Report: Safeguarding Style
 
WTR’s 
latest Special Report
 delves into the multifaceted landscape of brand creation and protection in the fashion and luxury industry, exploring the filing strategies, anti-counterfeiting technologies and international collaborations that are essential to success.

subject: Anti-counterfeiting messaging; border protection intelligence; filing trends
body:
11 January 2024 
Editor's Round-Up
This week on the WTR platform, we asked the director of economic action at the French IP office to reflect on the results of the France Anti-counterfeiting initiative. While the results pointed to improved enforcement efforts, they revealed worsening public awareness of the dangers of fake products. We explored how this 
could be tackled
. Elsewhere, we continued our series offering practical guidance on border protection strategies, focusing on 
Hong Kong
 and 
Uruguay
. We also scrutinised data on 2023 filings, revealing a positive uplift in applications across 
major Latin American
 and European jurisdictions. One exception was France, which saw 
a significant drop
 in the period we studied. 
 
Other trending content:
 
IP Australia replaces goods and services list; USPTO reveals executive appointments; IPOS unveils new trademark features
 
Legal Updates you may have missed: food and beverage success stories
 
“Enhancing accessibility and credibility”: Korean office expands on ambitious IP financing plans
 
The top trademark stories of 2023: WTR’s year in numbers
 
Trevor Little
Managing editor
Long Read
 
New arrangement for reciprocal enforcement of cross-border judgments to aid IP enforcement in China
 
Tanner De Witt’s Douglas Clark and Monique Woo explain why an arrangement taking effect this month for the cross-border enforcement of judgments offers brand owners a new weapon in the face of infringement in Hong Kong and Mainland China.
Read more
Market Insight 
Turkey 
Stock Intellectual Property Services AS 
Cancellation actions could surge as TÜRKPATENT and Court of Appeal remain at odds over acquired rights principle
 
Decisions from the Turkish Court of Appeal and the Turkish Patent and Trademark Office highlight practical differences between the two organisation’s processes. It is crucial for rights holders to understand these differences in order to best strengthen claims going forward.
Authors:
Merve Macit
 
Insight 
LexOrbis
 
Manisha Singh
 
Omesh Puri
 
India: Solutions for Addressing Grievances to Enhance Efficiency of Trademark Dispute Resolution
 
Featured in 
The Trademark Prosecution Review 2024
 
The Trade Marks Act plays a pivotal role in shaping India’s trademark registration and enforcement framework. With a focus on both registered and unregistered marks, it provides a robust system to protect trademark owners’ rights. Further, the creation of the IP division at the Delhi and Madras High Courts and the hiring of more hearing officers are significant steps toward improving the efficiency of trademark hearings and enforcement in India. 
Read more »
 
Uexküll & Stolberg
 
Alexander Thünken
 
Specialist Chapter: Key Cases Spotlight Challenges of Litigating Pharmaceutical Trademarks in Germany
 
Featured in 
The Trademark Litigation Review 2024
 
As highlighted by multiple CJEU, Supreme Court and Federal Patent Court judgments, creating a valid registration, the scope of protection, justifications for non-use of trademarks and objections to registration of infringing marks are among the most pressing issues when it comes to litigating pharmaceutical trademarks in Germany. 
Read more »
 
Events 
 
  12 - 13 March 2024 | London, UK 
WTR Live: Brand Strategy Summit Europe 2024
 
On 12 and 13 March, WTR Live: Brand Strategy Summit Europe is returning to London to bring together senior brand leaders, in-house trademark professionals, policy makers and their trusted legal advisers. 
Over the course of two days, this high-level conference will provide you with commercial and strategic insight, empowering your brand to overcome any challenges it may face, while maintaining its competitive edge.

subject: RE: Response to HubSpot List Import + other things
body:
Thanks Melissa. 
 
First, have we already paid you for your submitted hours? I hope so.
 
To be honest, at this point, given our financial situation, I’m not sure that the updated playbook is absolutely necessary. Not sure what HubSpot changes you refer to, but I can’t think of anything pressing right now on that front either. 
 
Hope your trip to Europe was amazing!
 
Rebecca M. Parrilla
(she/her)
Head of Client Solutions
LCW
 
 
From:
 Melissa Neu <m.neu@lcwmail.com> 
Sent:
 Friday, January 5, 2024 10:54 AM
To:
 Rebecca Parrilla <r.parrilla@lcwmail.com>
Cc:
 Pedro Seminario <P.seminario@lcwmail.com>; C. Melissa Neu <cmelissaneu2626@gmail.com>
Subject:
 RE: Response to HubSpot List Import + other things
 
Hi Rebecca,
 
I sincerely apologize for not getting back to you sooner. I rarely check LCW’s email. Briza and I talked about disconnecting it entirely, but it might impact access to HubSpot or DropBox, so it is open for now.
 
Regarding your questions, several of the lists you see in HubSpot are not related to sales but are instead related to marketing. These lists will be in the marketing drive, and Jake and I coordinated the imports to set up mailing lists, etc. Also, some Excel spreadsheets are exports from previous CRMs and might be source files that have since been cleaned to be uploaded to HubSpot. You may recall that when I started, we had Insightly CRM, then we stopped using it, then I built out Scoro and imported Insightly data to that system and then exported it, etc. If it doesn’t have a name like FD1, you can assume the content was cleaned and merged into HubSpot, most likely pulled from an earlier system.
 
I didn’t realize you don’t have access to my Dropbox folder – I thought all those folders were public. Let me look at it and see if there is anything I can do to help. At one point, I did create a private folder, which you might be referring to. That folder contains confidential information (such as HR); any lists or projects would be considered draft versions. However, access might help you if you need HR-related information. I will try sharing that with you as well.
 
I owe both you and Pedro an apology. The end of last year was a bit overwhelming, and I had to take on extra work, which caused me to fall behind on several projects. I still owe you the updated playbook, and HubSpot changes you mentioned below. If it is not too late to support you, I can get those to you next week. Please let me know if you’d like me to move forward or if there is anything else I can do to support you.
 
Kind regards,
 
Melissa  
 
 
C. Melissa Neu
(she/her)
Business Development Manager

From:
 Rebecca Parrilla <
r.parrilla@lcwmail.com
> 
Sent:
 Tuesday, December 5, 2023 1:34 PM
To:
 Melissa Neu <
m.neu@lcwmail.com
>
Cc:
 Pedro Seminario <
P.seminario@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 Response to HubSpot List Import + other things
 
Hi Melissa, 
 
How are you? I hope you had a lovely Thanksgiving, that your teaching and other things on your plate are going well, and that you’re having a good holiday season so far!
 
Re your email below….
 
Understood re: prospect contacts and the lists they came from.  I still don’t have a firm understanding on what each list represents but your categorization of what kinds of leads/prospects you pursued based on subject matter expertise, as well as based on specific messaging in emails or marketing, is helpful.  Plus you’ve mentioned to me in the past that anything labeled ‘warm leads’ were leads that came in through the LCW website. 
 
 
 
Thanks for the directions re: the Teams lists and the location of the source files in your SIDE PROJECTS folder. I moved that to SALES/sales ops/hubspot, for posterity.  Re: the Scoro source files, I unfortunately do not have access to the “Melissa Neu” folder under LCW Dropbox. 
 
Then, re: the filtering process you outlined below with the screenshots – these are contacts that were imported into HubSpot after various conferences or marketing events, right?  These are different from the imports from your SIDE PROJECT folder? Some filenames in this dropdown are self explanatory (e.g., “FDO-2022”), but some, like ‘people export’ or ‘mailchimp set up import’ – I’m not sure what those are. 
 
Finally and separately, on Nov 15 you emailed that by Monday Nov 20 you were going to share with me “an updated playbook with the HubSpot Instructions that you requested, have sent you a follow-up email to our last meeting with a few sources and clarifications 
(RP: that’s what this email was, I assume?)
, have the finalized consulting report view to you, and completed the final changes to the quote and proposal templates.”  Did I miss that? I haven’t seen it and I wanted to check.  
 
Thank you!!
RP
 
Rebecca M. Parrilla
(she/her)
Head of Client Solutions
LCW
 
From:
 Melissa Neu <
m.neu@lcwmail.com
> 
Sent:
 Tuesday, November 28, 2023 2:57 PM
To:
 Rebecca Parrilla <
r.parrilla@lcwmail.com
>
Cc:
 Pedro Seminario <
P.seminario@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 HubSpot List Import Follow-up
 
Dear Rebecca,
 
Thinking about our most recent conversation, I wanted to clarify a few things about HubSpot and the lists we uploaded into the system. One of HubSpot's great tools is the ability to assign leads, contacts, and companies to sales reps. For our purposes, the list that the contact came from was less important than knowing who it was assigned to and what the BD associate's expectations were when working with that lead. Often, Hannah and Pedro never saw the source file, but I would alert them when an upload was complete.
 
Now that your team has fewer and different people, it is hard to see that different contacts were assigned to different folks for different reasons. Our team would meet on average three times a week to coordinate. Unless it impacted messaging, it wasn't always necessary for us to know which of the lists the prospective client came from. Similarly, each member of our team had a different focus. In other words, Pedro would be focused on promoting translations and eLearning, Hannah would focus on facilitations, and I would concentrate on finding enterprise-wide clients (multi-modal learning opportunities) and consulting opportunities. The team was focused on this because we had varying subject matter knowledge and tenure at LCW. It also worked on the team's strengths – Pedro has extensive translation experience (for example) and eLearning. 
 
As I mentioned, the lists were only relevant as they pertained to specific messaging in emails or marketing. For example, the Forum attendees were on a list because we campaigned pre- and post-event. In contrast, we always invited folks from our assigned warm leads list to the events or promotions because folks on this list had submitted a website inquiry to LCW in the past three years. That doesn't mean that the Forum folks didn't get other communication, but in this example, we needed to differentiate that group based on messaging. 
 
To this end, while the three of us haven't talked much about the website integration or marketing side of HubSpot, one of the critical features we took advantage of was how leads were routed from the web. As outlined above, we would get leads assigned to us based on the client's indicated need or area of interest.
 
Taking advantage of HubSpot's capacity for sequencing, we didn't often need to refer to lists once the imports happened. Nevertheless, I completely understand your needs. Ultimately, this long-winded email is meant to share the following:
 
What you found in Teams was a snapshot of working documents pre-HubSpot implementation. However, I was diligent in keeping source files for all the uploads. The source files are kept here: LCW Dropbox\SIDE PROJECTS\MELISSA\CRM\HubSpot
Please note there are iterations here, and the documents are explicitly formatted for upload.
Some lists were cleaned and uploaded into Scoro first (such as the warm leads list.) By cleaning, we worked with the associate consultants and the intern to update all contact details, remove contacts that don't work at their job any longer, and either identify that person's replacement or find contact details for them in their new role (or both). If you ever want to look at those source files, you can find the Scoro uploads here: LCW Dropbox\Melissa Neu\Melissa's DropBox\ME\CRM.
Besides the lists we used in HubSpot for specific campaigns, you can always pull a list based on a previously uploaded file through filters. Here are the steps:
From the Contacts view, go to advanced filters: 
 
Click on advanced filters and then click on add filters:
 
After you click on add filters, you will be given a list of options to filter by. You will want to select "Import."
 
 
After selecting import, you will be given a list of options, and you can choose to select any list by name. You can also choose more than one list at a time. 
As soon as you click your list, the filter starts. Once filtered, you can assign these to someone, put them in a campaign, share them in a view, and/or put them into a list.
 
You will notice that some lists were marketing lists; those source files are kept here: \LCW Dropbox\MARKETING\HubSpot\Set-up. Please note that some of these contacts are captured in other lists. These uploads, at times, were only changing settings to ensure that folks subscribed to the mailing list were tagged in HubSpot.
 
I hope that this information provides more clarity as to where the source files are and how the system operates. Let me know if you have any questions or need me to walk you through this information.
 
Kind regards,
 
Melissa
 
 
C. Melissa Neu
(she/her)
Business Development Manager

subject: Reminder: Explore How Your Business Can Leverage AI in Our January 26 Webinar
body:
Recent advances in Artificial Intelligence as highlighted by ChatGPT are changing how we conduct business
View in browser
 
 
 
Artificial Intelligence — Crawl-Walk-Run: Crawl 
 
WEBINAR  |  January 26  |  1 – 2 p.m. CT

subject: Training Industry Weekly Recap 📅 Jan 7, 2024
body:
Upcoming Leader Talk, free training resources and more.
View this email in your browser
THE BUSINESS OF LEARNING™
With a new year upon us, now is the perfect time to solidify your professional goals for 2024. Whether you’re looking to gain a seat at the table, adopt artificial intelligence (AI)-powered solutions or improve training’s impact on the business, we’ve got resources that can help.
This week’s features include an 
upcoming Leader Talk
 on AI-powered learning solutions, a curated suite of free tools, templates and resources, and more — in addition to our usual roundup of articles.
Whatever your professional goals are, consider Training Industry your partner in all things the business of learning. Keep checking this weekly newsletter for curated articles and resources, upcoming events and more, and bookmark our website, TrainingIndustry.com, to stay up to date on the latest industry trends and advancements.
What are your career goals for 2024? Let us know on LinkedIn by tagging @TrainingIndustry. And as always, we welcome your feedback. Email us at 
editor@trainingindustry.com
 with your thoughts and ideas. 
Sarah Gallo, CPTM
Senior Editor 
[Leader Talk] AI-Powered Learning Solutions
Join us for our Jan. 31 
Leader Talk
 to delve into how AI is reshaping roles and revolutionizing course development, personalized learning, coaching feedback and more. Our panel of L&D experts will provide insights into leveraging AI for practical L&D applications and balancing its benefits while avoiding over-dependence. Don't miss this opportunity to learn about making AI your ally in navigating the dynamic world of L&D.
Reserve Your Spot
 
Tools, Templates and Other Free Resources on the Business of Learning
As the most trusted source of information on the business of learning, we at Training Industry make it our mission to provide learning leaders the tools they need to be successful. To make it easier for you to find those resources, we’ve compiled a collection of our 
free L&D templates and tools
. Check it out for e-books, job aids, infographics, templates and more — all designed to make your role more manageable.
Learn More
 
Top 10 Articles of 2023
Be sure to check out the 2023 highlights from TrainingIndustry.com and Training Industry Magazine. We published over 800 articles from global training experts and thought leaders, featuring invaluable insights related to leadership development, effective measurement strategies, transformative learning and much more. Dive into the 
top 10 articles of 2023
 and explore the ideas that shaped an extraordinary year in training.
View the List
 
[E-Book] Updating 70-20-10 for the 21st Century   
The landscape of the training industry is changing quickly, thanks to evolving learner expectations and preferences as well as technological advances. This report seeks to update the concept of the 70-20-10 model to the present day from its inception over 30 years ago, by evaluating data on how employees learn at work. Based on survey results from 1,569 working professionals, 
this e-book
 can help you structure your training programs to meet the needs of your organization.

subject: Verizon’s award-winning year; Banksy turns to designs; Customs enforcement tips; and much more
body:
WTR SUNDAY DIGEST
07 January 2024
 
Verizon’s award-winning year; Banksy turns to designs; Customs enforcement tips; and much more
Everything we covered on WTR over the past seven days, and all you need to know from the world of trademarks to set yourself up for the start of another busy week.
Long Read
Rouse’s Amanda Yang and Jasmine Lv look at examination criteria and strategies 
for trademark owners to adopt
 in the face of potentially misleading or negative marks.
Monday 1 January
After more than doubling at the start of the year, foreign filings at the China National Intellectual Property Administration returned 
to a more typical level
 in mid-2023.
Corsearch’s Mike Sweeney examines 
the wide-reaching effects
 of the EU Digital Services Act on IP protection and e-commerce.
Tuesday 2 January
Verizon’s Patrick Flaherty reflects on 
an award-winning year
 and why brand owners need to make use of ICANN’s Registration Data Request Service.
Tuesday’s news digest includes coverage of Erling Haaland continuing his trademark haul, Cincinnati CBP seizing $7 million in counterfeit jewellery and 
the surging brand value
 of the Indian Premier League.
Plus:
General Court confirms similarity of lightning bolt marks
 (European Union)
Application for BENJAMIN BROWN: is Mr Benjamin Brown around?
 (Japan)
Wednesday 3 January
The EUIPO has partially cancelled a trademark owned 
by street artist Banksy
, including across goods and services related to clothing.
Yemen cancels trademarks belonging to US companies and the heads of the G7 IP offices 
meet in the metaverse
. 
We present insights on 
working with Customs
 in Paraguay.
Plus: 
A ‘tail’ of enforcing descriptive marks: lessons from VETSURE v PETSURE
 (United Kingdom)
Law No 08/L-075 on Trademarks: legal opportunities for the imposition of fines against infringers
 (Kosovo)
Thursday 4 January
Trademark applications at the French National Institute of Industrial 
Property fell between 1 May and 31 August 2023
, as filings at other registers in North America and Europe grew, data reveals. 
Plus:
Commentary that is commercial risks loss of First Amendment protection
 (United States)
CROSSFIT v CROSSWOD: General Court skips over assessment of CROSSFIT’s enhanced acquired distinctiveness
 (European Union)
Federal Circuit vacates TTAB decision in dispute between two religious organisations
 (Market Insight: United States)
Key 2023 trademark updates in Albania, Montenegro and Slovenia
 (Market Insight: Western Balkans)
How amendments to the Trademark Act have helped align Norway with the rest of Europe
 (Market Insight: Scandinavia) 
Friday 5 January
We head to Hong Kong 
for brand protection advice
 at the border.
A ‘brand-friendly’ metaverse prepares to launch, diversity challenges in Nepal’s legal sector are explored, law firms 
announce January promotions
, and more
Brand owners battling infringement in Türkiye should be aware of the Customs Liquidation Service and IP programme 
available to help
 prevent fake goods entering the market.
Plus:
Delhi High Court: no defence under Section 30(2)(e) if defendant’s registration does not cover goods for which mark is used
 (India)
EUROPATENT case considers Re-examination and Evaluation Board’s discretion to examine absolute grounds for refusal
 (Türkiye)
Saturday 6 January
Scams targeting trademark applicants, IP office innovation and dispatches from the INTA Annual Meeting all feature prominently on the list of WTR’s 
list of most-read content
 in 2023.
 
You may have missed…
Returning from the holiday season? Here’s what you may have missed on the WTR platform: 
What the future holds for AI and IP
US district courts almost guaranteed to grant service by alternate means as filings surge
China's most important cases of the year
A pivotal moment with "big plans" ahead – INTA’s year in review
Trademark highlights from EU courts – 2023 and cases to watch in 2024
BAD SPANIELS, Abitron and Redbubble – 2023’s most influential US decisions
Societal changes, increased demand and customer satisfaction – UKIPO’s year in review
AI booms as overall filing activity returns to normal – 2023 at major trademark offices
Fighting counterfeiting and piracy across Latin America – Mercado Libre's year in review
Special Report: Safeguarding Style
WTR’s
 
latest Special Report
 
delves into the multifaceted landscape of brand creation and protection in the fashion and luxury industry, exploring the filing strategies, anti-counterfeiting technologies and international collaborations that are essential to success.
Subscribe
Follow us on LinkedIn 
  and Twitter 
 
Law Business Research 
- Registered office: Holborn Gate, 330 High Holborn, WC1V 7QT, London, United Kingdom. 
Registered in England and Wales number 03281866
Manage your email preferences, unsubscribe or opt out.
To receive our emails without interruption, please add us to your safe senders list.

subject: RE: Response to HubSpot List Import + other things
body:
Hi Rebecca,
 
I sincerely apologize for not getting back to you sooner. I rarely check LCW’s email. Briza and I talked about disconnecting it entirely, but it might impact access to HubSpot or DropBox, so it is open for now.
 
Regarding your questions, several of the lists you see in HubSpot are not related to sales but are instead related to marketing. These lists will be in the marketing drive, and Jake and I coordinated the imports to set up mailing lists, etc. Also, some Excel spreadsheets are exports from previous CRMs and might be source files that have since been cleaned to be uploaded to HubSpot. You may recall that when I started, we had Insightly CRM, then we stopped using it, then I built out Scoro and imported Insightly data to that system and then exported it, etc. If it doesn’t have a name like FD1, you can assume the content was cleaned and merged into HubSpot, most likely pulled from an earlier system.
 
I didn’t realize you don’t have access to my Dropbox folder – I thought all those folders were public. Let me look at it and see if there is anything I can do to help. At one point, I did create a private folder, which you might be referring to. That folder contains confidential information (such as HR); any lists or projects would be considered draft versions. However, access might help you if you need HR-related information. I will try sharing that with you as well.
 
I owe both you and Pedro an apology. The end of last year was a bit overwhelming, and I had to take on extra work, which caused me to fall behind on several projects. I still owe you the updated playbook, and HubSpot changes you mentioned below. If it is not too late to support you, I can get those to you next week. Please let me know if you’d like me to move forward or if there is anything else I can do to support you.
 
Kind regards,
 
Melissa

From:

To:
 Melissa Neu <m.neu@lcwmail.com>
Cc:
 Pedro Seminario <P.seminario@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 Response to HubSpot List Import + other things
 
Hi Melissa, 
 
How are you? I hope you had a lovely Thanksgiving, that your teaching and other things on your plate are going well, and that you’re having a good holiday season so far!
 
Re your email below….
 
Understood re: prospect contacts and the lists they came from.  I still don’t have a firm understanding on what each list represents but your categorization of what kinds of leads/prospects you pursued based on subject matter expertise, as well as based on specific messaging in emails or marketing, is helpful.  Plus you’ve mentioned to me in the past that anything labeled ‘warm leads’ were leads that came in through the LCW website. 
 
 
 
Thanks for the directions re: the Teams lists and the location of the source files in your SIDE PROJECTS folder. I moved that to SALES/sales ops/hubspot, for posterity.  Re: the Scoro source files, I unfortunately do not have access to the “Melissa Neu” folder under LCW Dropbox. 
 
Then, re: the filtering process you outlined below with the screenshots – these are contacts that were imported into HubSpot after various conferences or marketing events, right?  These are different from the imports from your SIDE PROJECT folder? Some filenames in this dropdown are self explanatory (e.g., “FDO-2022”), but some, like ‘people export’ or ‘mailchimp set up import’ – I’m not sure what those are. 
 
Finally and separately, on Nov 15 you emailed that by Monday Nov 20 you were going to share with me “an updated playbook with the HubSpot Instructions that you requested, have sent you a follow-up email to our last meeting with a few sources and clarifications 
(RP: that’s what this email was, I assume?)
, have the finalized consulting report view to you, and completed the final changes to the quote and proposal templates.”  Did I miss that? I haven’t seen it and I wanted to check.  
 
Thank you!!
RP
 
Rebecca M. Parrilla
(she/her)
Head of Client Solutions
LCW
 
From:
 Melissa Neu <
m.neu@lcwmail.com
> 
Sent:
 Tuesday, November 28, 2023 2:57 PM
To:
 Rebecca Parrilla <
r.parrilla@lcwmail.com
>
Cc:
 Pedro Seminario <
P.seminario@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 HubSpot List Import Follow-up
 
Dear Rebecca,
 
Thinking about our most recent conversation, I wanted to clarify a few things about HubSpot and the lists we uploaded into the system. One of HubSpot's great tools is the ability to assign leads, contacts, and companies to sales reps. For our purposes, the list that the contact came from was less important than knowing who it was assigned to and what the BD associate's expectations were when working with that lead. Often, Hannah and Pedro never saw the source file, but I would alert them when an upload was complete.
 
Now that your team has fewer and different people, it is hard to see that different contacts were assigned to different folks for different reasons. Our team would meet on average three times a week to coordinate. Unless it impacted messaging, it wasn't always necessary for us to know which of the lists the prospective client came from. Similarly, each member of our team had a different focus. In other words, Pedro would be focused on promoting translations and eLearning, Hannah would focus on facilitations, and I would concentrate on finding enterprise-wide clients (multi-modal learning opportunities) and consulting opportunities. The team was focused on this because we had varying subject matter knowledge and tenure at LCW. It also worked on the team's strengths – Pedro has extensive translation experience (for example) and eLearning. 
 
As I mentioned, the lists were only relevant as they pertained to specific messaging in emails or marketing. For example, the Forum attendees were on a list because we campaigned pre- and post-event. In contrast, we always invited folks from our assigned warm leads list to the events or promotions because folks on this list had submitted a website inquiry to LCW in the past three years. That doesn't mean that the Forum folks didn't get other communication, but in this example, we needed to differentiate that group based on messaging. 
 
To this end, while the three of us haven't talked much about the website integration or marketing side of HubSpot, one of the critical features we took advantage of was how leads were routed from the web. As outlined above, we would get leads assigned to us based on the client's indicated need or area of interest.
 
Taking advantage of HubSpot's capacity for sequencing, we didn't often need to refer to lists once the imports happened. Nevertheless, I completely understand your needs. Ultimately, this long-winded email is meant to share the following:
 
What you found in Teams was a snapshot of working documents pre-HubSpot implementation. However, I was diligent in keeping source files for all the uploads. The source files are kept here: LCW Dropbox\SIDE PROJECTS\MELISSA\CRM\HubSpot
Please note there are iterations here, and the documents are explicitly formatted for upload.
Some lists were cleaned and uploaded into Scoro first (such as the warm leads list.) By cleaning, we worked with the associate consultants and the intern to update all contact details, remove contacts that don't work at their job any longer, and either identify that person's replacement or find contact details for them in their new role (or both). If you ever want to look at those source files, you can find the Scoro uploads here: LCW Dropbox\Melissa Neu\Melissa's DropBox\ME\CRM.
Besides the lists we used in HubSpot for specific campaigns, you can always pull a list based on a previously uploaded file through filters. Here are the steps:
From the Contacts view, go to advanced filters: 
 
Click on advanced filters and then click on add filters:
 
After you click on add filters, you will be given a list of options to filter by. You will want to select "Import."
 
 
After selecting import, you will be given a list of options, and you can choose to select any list by name. You can also choose more than one list at a time. 
As soon as you click your list, the filter starts. Once filtered, you can assign these to someone, put them in a campaign, share them in a view, and/or put them into a list.
 
You will notice that some lists were marketing lists; those source files are kept here: \LCW Dropbox\MARKETING\HubSpot\Set-up. Please note that some of these contacts are captured in other lists. These uploads, at times, were only changing settings to ensure that folks subscribed to the mailing list were tagged in HubSpot.
 
I hope that this information provides more clarity as to where the source files are and how the system operates. Let me know if you have any questions or need me to walk you through this information.
 
Kind regards,
 
Melissa
 
 
C. Melissa Neu
(she/her)
Business Development Manager

subject: Blow for Banksy; 2024 predictions; metaverse filings plummet
body:
04 January 2024 
Editor's Round-Up
This week on the WTR platform we reported on an EUIPO decision to partially cancel a trademark owned by street artist Banksy. The move comes 
against a backdrop
 of Banksy, who famously claimed that “copyright is for losers”, expanding his IP portfolio to designs. Elsewhere, we marked the end of 2023 by asking a range of IP leaders – from organisations including 
INTA
, 
Verizon
, 
the UK Intellectual Property Office
 and 
Mercado Libre
 – to reflect on learnings from the past 12 months and predict what 2024 has in store for brand professionals. We also presented analysis of trademark filing trends at offices around the world, with a steady fall in applications for marks 
related to NFTs and the metaverse
.
 
Other trending content:
USPTO year in review 2023: exclusive interview with trademark commissioner David Gooder
 
What the future holds for AI and IP
 
US district courts almost guaranteed to grant service by alternate means as filings surge
 
Yemen cancels trademarks belonging to US companies
Trevor Little
Managing editor
Long Read
 
How to prevent your trademarks from being deemed as “misleading” or having a “negative influence” in China
 
Are your trademarks potentially misleading? Or can they be deemed as having a negative influence on society? Both of these are grounds for cancellation in China. Rouse’s Amanda Yang and Jasmine Lv look at examination criteria and trends, provide relevant examples and highlight strategies for trademark owners to adopt.
Read more
Market Insight 
USA 
McDermott Will & Emery 
Federal Circuit vacates TTAB decision in dispute between two religious organisations
 
Drawing on previous opposition claims, the Federal Circuit has voided the board’s decision to sustain the opposition between two non-denominational internet churches. The decision highlights issues of waiver in trademark disputes that involve multi-class applications.
Authors:
Paul Devinsky
 
Scandinavia 
Zacco 
How amendments to the Trademark Act have helped align Norway with the rest of Europe
 
Amendments to the Norwegian Trademark Act, which entered into force on 1 March 2023, have brought the country into line with current European legislation and directives. Exploring some of these changes reveals how they may impact registration decision making.
Authors:
Solvår Winnie Finnanger
 
Western Balkans 
Patent & Trade Mark Agency MIHAILOVIC 
Key 2023 trademark updates in Albania, Montenegro and Slovenia
 
It is crucial that brand owners are aware of the legislative changes that came into force last year in the Western Balkans. A deep understanding of these developments will ensure effective trademark management and compliance going forward.
Authors:
Mila Mihailovic
 
Insight 
Hylands Law firm
 
Yingzi Liu
 
Erica Liu
 
Qingqing Jia
 
Cindy Wang
 
How the latest monetisation methods can be used to grow a brand’s value in China
 
Featured in 
Inside China’s IP Market: a Guide 2024
 
Brand monetisation is an inevitable necessity for companies to enhance their core competitiveness and achieve innovative management. It is therefore imperative to explore the main ways to monetise a brand under China’s current legal environment. 
Read more »
 
Uhthoff, Gómez Vega & Uhthoff SC
 
Saúl Santoyo Orozco
 
Jose Luis Ramos-Zurita
 
Mexico: Refreshed regime takes aim at administrative infringements and criminal counterfeiting
 
Featured in 
Anti-counterfeiting and Online Brand Enforcement: Global Guide 2023
 
Significant changes to domestic IP regulations following the United States-Mexico-Canada agreement and a more proactive approach to the trade in fakes is good news for rights holders. 
Read more »
 
Events 
 
  12 - 13 March 2024 | London, UK 
WTR Live: Brand Strategy Summit Europe 2024
 
On 12 and 13 March, WTR Live: Brand Strategy Summit Europe is returning to London to bring together senior brand leaders, in-house trademark professionals, policy makers and their trusted legal advisers. 
 
Over the course of two days, this high-level conference will provide you with commercial and strategic insight, empowering your brand to overcome any challenges it may face, while maintaining its competitive edge.

subject: Full Calendar - Upcoming Events
body:
You don't often get email from calendar@fromdayone.co. 
Learn why this is important
 From Day One is pleased to invite you to our upcoming events, each accredited by SHRM and HRCI, unless otherwise noted.
 
View this email in your browser
 
 
From Day One is pleased to invite you to our upcoming events
Our weekly 
webinars
 are each 60 minutes, complimentary to attend, and qualify for 1 credit from SHRM and HRCI.
Our monthly half-day 
virtual conferences 
include keynote, fireside chat, and panel discussions on our virtual main stage, as well as workshop sessions, chat, and one-on-one networking opportunities that facilitate interaction with our presenters and your fellow participants. They each qualify for 3 credits from SHRM and HRCI.
Our 
live events
 are coming to a city near you. Each one-day conference brings together leading thinkers and top executives in HR, talent acquisition, diversity, employee engagement, benefits, and CSR for an engaging, up-to-the-minute conversation about how employers can build stronger bonds of trust and connection with their workers and their communities. They each qualify for 4 credits from SHRM and HRCI.
Our 
half-day live events
 bring together leading thinkers and top executives in more focused sectors. They each qualify for 3 credits from SHRM and HRCI. 
VIRTUAL CONFERENCE
 
January 10: A Fresh Commitment to a Culture of Well-Being
While many employers recognize the connection between well-being and productivity, creating a healthy balance in the real world of work can be challenging. What are the key choices and thoughtful compromises that must be made for workers to thrive as well as produce? How can managers be trained to make the well-being of their workers a top priority? How can companies get a better sense of which benefits and rewards are most effective–and encourage workers to take advantage of them? 
Register now
.
LIVE EVENT
 
January 24: Atlanta, GA - Building a Culture for Workers and Companies to Thrive in Times of Change
In an era of digital transformation and rising employee expectations, companies will need to become even more attuned to the needs and aspirations of workers to keep them engaged and satisfied on their career paths. And in an environment of hybrid work and strained profits, employers will have to focus on making work both efficient and sustainable. How can companies do more with less, while maintaining employee well-being? What are the next frontiers in talent acquisition, employee benefits, learning and development, and diversity, equity, inclusion and belonging? 
Register now
.
WEBINAR
 
February 1: How Lifestyle Spending Accounts (LSAs) Revitalize Benefits for the Most Employee Flexibility and ROI
Despite the proliferation of employee-centric benefits, a prevalent issue persists where benefits packages are filled with underutilized programs. For employers, this is an inefficient use of capital; for employees, it’s a missed opportunity. In this webinar, Forma, a leader in the flexible benefit space and Lifestyle Spending Account (LSA) domain, will explore what an LSA is, how these customizable spending accounts support employees' individual needs, the state of the benefits market, and why the option has proven to be a solution that checks many essential boxes (i.e., cost efficiency, savings, personalization, productivity). You will leave with actionable insights from Forma’s 2023 LSA benchmark report -- with data collected from more than 200 companies and 450,000 employees worldwide -- so you can design best-in-class LSAs that employees will love. 
Register now
.
LIVE EVENT
 
February 6: Houston, TX - Building a Culture for Workers and Companies to Thrive in Times of Change
In an era of digital transformation and rising employee expectations, companies will need to become even more attuned to the needs and aspirations of workers to keep them engaged and satisfied on their career paths. And in an environment of hybrid work and strained profits, employers will have to focus on making work both efficient and sustainable. How can companies do more with less, while maintaining employee well-being? What are the next frontiers in talent acquisition, employee benefits, learning and development, and diversity, equity, inclusion and belonging? 
Register now
.
WEBINAR
 
February 8: Eating Disorders: How Employers Can Help People Recover at Home
Eating disorders affect nearly one in 10 Americans, and the numbers continue to rise. Among mental-health disorders, these illnesses have the second-highest mortality rate. Yet traditional care, including hospitalization and outpatient programs, can be difficult to access, distant, and costly. A better way has emerged. In this webinar, you'll hear how Accolade, a personalized healthcare platform, works with Equip, a 100% virtual, family-based treatment program that’s built into daily schedules, so people can recover right at home. You'll learn from experts how this evidence-based treatment model can help people without uprooting their lives, while building support in the real world and working toward lasting recovery. 
Register now
.
WEBINAR
 
February 13: Using Structured Hiring to Make the Process Smoother and Quicker at Every Stage
For both employers and candidates, the hiring process can break down and sow frustration. But there's a better way. With a thoughtful structure and sequencing, employers can find and bring talent onboard much more efficiently and with greater transparency. The improvements can be in planning (better communication between hiring managers and recruiters), sourcing (gathering the right talent to your pipeline), interviewing (shortening the lag time between stages), and onboarding (meeting the needs of new hires faster). AI and automation can reduce manual work for recruiters, as well as helping enterprise companies to hire at scale. Please join us for a fireside chat with Jon Stross, president of the hiring software platform Greenhouse, who will show how structured hiring can improve the process from beginning to end. 
Register now
.
VIRTUAL CONFERENCE
 
February 14: Getting to the Next Stage of Diversity and Belonging
At a time of resistance and corporate austerity, DEI advocates will need to re-energize themselves and their organizations with new ideas, programs, and reasoning for the cause of diversity. What can DEI practitioners learn from companies with consistent success? How are companies changing their policies to respond to court rulings and lawsuits? What practices have brought the most progress in bringing diversity to leadership ranks? 
Register now
.

.
VIRTUAL CONFERENCE
 
March 6: Employee Engagement: Tapping the Secrets of Energizing Workers
Companies want their employees to be enthused and involved, yet employers need to be thoughtful in fostering these qualities in authentic ways. What’s the latest thinking about how employers can understand the motivations of their workers–and how to respond? What are the best methods for recognizing achievement, both individually and among teams? What’s the connection between engagement and job satisfaction? In the hybrid work environment, what binds workers together and wards off anxiety and loneliness? 
Register now
.
WEBINAR
 
March 19: Sharing their Truths: Working Parents Reveal What Benefits Matter Most
Each year, HR leaders ask themselves: What benefits do my employees want? And what will provide me the most ROI? But many are left without answers. Until now. Join us for this exclusive fireside chat webinar with leaders from Ovia Health will explain the results of a new survey where working parents explain how they feel about their current benefits, where they need more support and what matters most to them. 
Register now
.
LIVE EVENT - HALF DAY
 
March 20: Boston, MA - Benefits in 2024 and Beyond: Innovative and Inclusive Approaches for Worker Well-Being and Cost Effectiveness
A wide range of benefits allows employers to tackle a broad spectrum of their goals, spanning from retaining and engaging employees to promoting diversity and inclusion within the workplace. What are the cutting-edge benefits available that cater to the needs of every worker? How can companies evaluate their workforce needs and cultivate awareness and participation in their offerings? What trends are emerging and what can be expected in the future of benefits?

.
VIRTUAL CONFERENCE
 
April 3: Benefits That Fit Individual Needs Without Busting the Budget
Having made a commitment to recognize the unique needs of individuals, the secret is in the execution. What are the emerging benefits and rewards that workers are seeking, from fertility care to financial wellness? How can companies use technology to stay in close touch with what individuals are experiencing–and where they need help as a result? How can companies choose among myriad point solutions and innovative new platforms? What are the most cost-effective rewards in terms of investments and outcomes? 
Register now
.
LIVE EVENT
 
April 9: Chicago, IL - Building a Culture for Workers and Companies to Thrive in Times of Change
In an era of digital transformation and rising employee expectations, companies will need to become even more attuned to the needs and aspirations of workers to keep them engaged and satisfied on their career paths. And in an environment of hybrid work and strained profits, employers will have to focus on making work both efficient and sustainable. How can companies do more with less, while maintaining employee well-being? What are the next frontiers in talent acquisition, employee benefits, learning and development, and diversity, equity, inclusion and belonging? 
Register now
.
LIVE EVENT
 
April 23: Dallas, TX - Building a Culture for Workers and Companies to Thrive in Times of Change
In an era of digital transformation and rising employee expectations, companies will need to become even more attuned to the needs and aspirations of workers to keep them engaged and satisfied on their career paths. And in an environment of hybrid work and strained profits, employers will have to focus on making work both efficient and sustainable. How can companies do more with less, while maintaining employee well-being? What are the next frontiers in talent acquisition, employee benefits, learning and development, and diversity, equity, inclusion and belonging? 
Register now
.
WEBINAR
 
April 25: How to Provide Fertility Benefits Without Breaking the Bank
Infertility is a common issue. According to the WHO, infertility affects one in every six couples who are trying to conceive at some point in their lives. Despite the magnitude of the issue, solutions for the prevention, diagnosis and treatment can be inaccessible due to high costs, stigma, and limited availability. What’s more, a new report suggests only 15% of employees have access to infertility coverage. Many employers want to provide coverage, but aren’t sure how to do so without overinflating benefits costs. In this webinar, leaders will share sustainable strategies for funding fertility benefits that can actually save employers on medical costs. 
Register now
.
LIVE EVENT
 
May 14: Minneapolis, MN - Building a Culture for Workers and Companies to Thrive in Times of Change
In an era of digital transformation and rising employee expectations, companies will need to become even more attuned to the needs and aspirations of workers to keep them engaged and satisfied on their career paths. And in an environment of hybrid work and strained profits, employers will have to focus on making work both efficient and sustainable. How can companies do more with less, while maintaining employee well-being? What are the next frontiers in talent acquisition, employee benefits, learning and development, and diversity, equity, inclusion and belonging? 
Register now
.
VIRTUAL CONFERENCE
 
May 22: The Art and Science of Employee Retention, Coaching and Advancement
While the pace of job-hopping has eased, employers have a powerful motivation to retain skilled workers, both for financial and cultural reasons. How can employers use new tools, including AI, to gain insights about what’s inspiring their workers to stay committed–or walk out the door? Since attrition is often caused by poor relationships with managers, what are innovative ways for employers to train their workers to be better leaders at a time when workers have higher expectations for job satisfaction? How can technology help make coaching more effective? 
Register now
.
LIVE EVENT
 
May 23: Manhattan, NY - Building a Culture for Workers and Companies to Thrive in Times of Change
In an era of digital transformation and rising employee expectations, companies will need to become even more attuned to the needs and aspirations of workers to keep them engaged and satisfied on their career paths. And in an environment of hybrid work and strained profits, employers will have to focus on making work both efficient and sustainable. How can companies do more with less, while maintaining employee well-being? What are the next frontiers in talent acquisition, employee benefits, learning and development, and diversity, equity, inclusion and belonging? 
Register now
.
WEBINAR
 
June 4: Paving the Way for All Paths to Parenthood
Studies indicate that 29% of LGBTQ+ couples are raising children, and 63% of millennial LGBTQ+ couples are hoping to expand their family in the near future. But, surrogacy typically costs $60-100k per child. If your current family building benefits aren’t built to support these expenses and every path to parenthood, they may not be inclusive enough to meet your DEIB, retention or talent acquisition goals. Join this webinar to learn how to evolve your benefits to be more inclusive, and ways to support surrogacy, egg/sperm donorship, adoption/fostering. 
Register now
.
VIRTUAL CONFERENCE
 
June 12: 
Bringing Talent Acquisition into the Digital Age
Despite layoffs making headlines now, all the demographic and digital trends point toward tough competition for workers in the future–maybe sooner than most expect. What are the new techniques and tools that talent-acquisition can use to envision the workforce their company will need in the future? What data and insights can HR and TA leaders provide to the company to be ahead of trends? How can companies do a better job of internal recruiting and promoting internal mobility? What are the best practices for hiring based on skills and potential, rather than credentials? 
Register now
.
VIRTUAL CONFERENCE
 
July 10: Learning and Development: How New Tools Are Changing Upskilling and Career Mobility
As employers put more emphasis on skills as the currency for worker development, they’re seeking new ways to measure them, fill in gaps, and predict the skills needed in the future. How can these new tools, including AI, create better matches between employees and projects? How can employers gain insights from the data they gather? Why do real-world simulations help measure certain skills better than traditional assessments? 
Register now
.
VIRTUAL CONFERENCE
 
July 17: Innovative Benefits That Support Healthy Families and Caregivers
As the pandemic’s caregiving crisis showed, employers found significant gaps in their support for the parents and other caregivers in their workforces. The resulting scramble to help has produced a wealth of new HR policies, benefit offerings, and management practices. Where is the greatest demand for support, as well as the most innovative new methods? What have been the most cost-effective ways to help caregivers of all kinds, including parents as well as “sandwich generation” workers caring for elderly and disabled relatives? 
Register now
.

subject: Training Industry Weekly Recap 📅 Dec. 31, 2023
body:
New podcast episode, sustainability survey and more.
View this email in your browser
THE BUSINESS OF LEARNING™
Tomorrow’s the first day of the new year (we can’t believe it either)! Take a look back at the 
top 10 articles
 from our website and Training Industry Magazine to see the insights, analysis and more that resonated with your peers in 2023.
It’s the perfect time to work on your learning and development (L&D) strategy for the coming year. Our 
annual trends report
 will help you understand the six key trends that will influence the training industry in the year ahead.
And if you’ve been neglecting your own professional development, now’s the time for a fresh start. Our 
2024 courses catalog
 is out now: Whether you’re interested in getting credentialed in our Certified Professional in Training Management (CPTM™) program or upskilling yourself in specific competencies, there are numerous options to help you advance your career.
As always, we love hearing from you! Reach out to 
editor@trainingindustry.com
 with any questions, comments or article ideas. Thank you for reading — we’ll see you in 2024! 
Mike Allen, CPTM
Editor 
2023’s Must-Reads: Top 10 Articles of the Year
As we close a groundbreaking year in the training industry, let's rewind and celebrate the highlights from TrainingIndustry.com and Training Industry Magazine. We published over 800 articles from global training experts and thought leaders, featuring invaluable insights related to leadership development, effective measurement strategies, transformative learning and much more. top 10 articles of 2023
 and explore the ideas that have shaped an extraordinary year in training.
View the List
 
New Year, New Trends: L&D's 2024 Outlook
Our 
annual trends report
 not only highlights the growing importance of L&D in organizational success, but also delves into how it’s reshaping workforce dynamics. Discover six pivotal trends set to shape the future of corporate training, including talent retention improvements, AI integration, enhanced learner engagement and the resurgence of instructor-led training. Dive into this comprehensive guide now to stay ahead in the evolving landscape of L&D as we embrace a new year of opportunities and challenges.

Make Professional Development Your Priority in 2024
Plan to get ahead and stay ahead in the new year by prioritizing your professional development. The 
2024 Training Industry Courses catalog
 is out now! Whether you are looking to become a CPTM and gain a foundational knowledge of training management or upskill yourself on a specific competency, such as creating a custom competency model, Training Industry Courses are here to help you reach your goals. subject: Training Industry Weekly Recap 📅 Dec. 24, 2023
body:
New podcast episode, sustainability survey and more.
View this email in your browser
THE BUSINESS OF LEARNING™
As we head into the last week of 2023, I just want to thank you for being a part of our training community — whether it was by attending one of our webinars or courses, publishing or reading an article, listening to our podcast or connecting with us in person at the Training Industry Conference & Expo (TICE) this past June. Our team is dedicated to providing this community with the resources you need to develop great training, and it has been a pleasure to support you on your career journey.
We have curated a collection of great resources for you in this newsletter that I hope you enjoy. And as always, we love hearing from you, so please reach out with any questions to 
editor@trainingindustry.com
 with suggestions.
Michelle Eggleston Schwartz
CPTM, Editor in Chief 
The Business of Learning, Episode 71: Learning Reinforcement — Delivering Training That “Sticks”
Delivering “sticky” learning programs that encourage learning retention over time is key to realizing the business benefits of training and development. To learn more about learning reinforcement strategies, we spoke with Elena Agaragimova, a talent development specialist, author and podcaster, and Rachel Walerstein, CPTM, senior manager of learning and talent development for the AIDS Foundation of Chicago, in the 
latest episode
 of The Business of Learning.
Listen Now
 
Share Your Thoughts on Sustainability
Sustainability is an increasingly critical part of shaping organizational strategy. We want to hear about your experience with sustainability in the training function. Your insights are invaluable! Participate in our brief survey to voice your perspective and gain exclusive access to our dynamic Training Manager Competency Report dashboard. Let’s collaborate to build a greener future!
Take the Survey
 
TICE 2024 Early Bird Registration
Ready to elevate your L&D strategy this summer? Join us at the 
Training Industry Conference & Expo (TICE)
, June 4-6, 2024 in Raleigh, N.C. Immerse yourself in three days of dynamic learning and networking with a vibrant community of training professionals. Together, we'll connect, collaborate and uncover innovative solutions for today's training challenges. Secure your spot by Dec. 31 to lock in our early bird rate of $1,495. Don’t miss this opportunity to transform, learn and grow with us!
Register Now
 
Last Chance to Save With Our Courses and Research Winter Sale     
It’s the final days of the 
Training Industry Courses
 and 
Training Industry Research
 winter sale! Take advantage of this opportunity to receive discounts on all Training Industry Courses and Research. This includes certifications, certificates, workshops, learning journeys and our extensive portfolio of research reports on the latest training market and L&D trends. Now 
through Dec. 31
, use code 
FROZEN10 for 10% off
 any course or research report.
Claim Your Discount
